body: Based on the description in DAFFODIL-1989 I updated the tests unparseDelimitedPaddedString09 and unparsePaddedString10 to not expect the additional padding to make it reach minLength, which I am assuming is correct behaviour based on the erratum.  If someone could verify this for me I would appreciate it and I will update the test descriptions to reflect this.
I believe this is correct: lengthKind 'explicit' means minLength is used for validation only.
Funnily enough I had already made the warning text more general, but hadn't yet written out the file when I made the commit.  Should be included now in the most recent commit.
+1 with removal or changes of commented out code
Should be good to go now with the most recent commit
They've deprecated jdk10 in favor of jdk11. Looks like no one will be able to use jdk10 on travis CI anymore.
So, JDK10 sure seemed to have a short lifespan before being deprecated. Was some egregious security bug found in it or something?

Oracle is speeding up their release cycles so a new release happens something like every 6 months. Then on a longer cycle, like every three years, they pick a release to be the LTS release. Java 11 is that LTS, so people are told to no longer use Java 9 or 10.
Wasn't really sure of a practical way to add a test for this case.  I did test it with the CLI tool by manually decreasing the memory available it it does work.

I have incorporated all the feedback from this code review into the code base. 

However, the change set is quite large, and quite a bit more refactoring was done. So it doesn't really make sense to continue this review by adding more changes to this. I'm going to start a new PR.
This is DAFFODIL-2204. Will add to the commit message.

Turns out things still don't work with OpenJDK. TravisCI is able to install that version, but our version of SBT depends on Scala 2.12, which doesn't work on OpenJDK 7. This isn't surprising since Scala 2.12 required Java 8, so the question is why did it work at all on Oracle JDK 7 before? Not sure it's woth the effort to figure it out--Java 7 has been EOL for few years. So I think we should just remove Java7 from TravisCI.

Note that the jars we cross compile with Scala 2.11 shoudl still work on Java 7, so Daffodil can still run on older stystems, we just can't perform automated nightlies. So perhaps we can say it should work on Java 7, but it's not officially supported anymore.

So we have a few things that are annoying given the proliferation of projects. One is this number, the other is the scala compiler version number. These need to be centralized, or mostly so. Can one just set this in one place?

Do you mean how all the different DFDL schemas also need to include an sbt and scala version number? I don't think there is a great way around that. The sbt version number definiately can't be centralized, since the build.properties file has a very simple format and is parsed very earily in the sbt startup process.

The scala version can be a little more dynamic, but I don't think there is a way to query the scala version that Daffodil uses. The best we could probably do is create an SBT plugin that the DFDL Schema projects use, and that plugin could be manually updated to match the Daffodil version. Then it just becomes a matter of updating that plugin. But that's kindof odd behavior for a plugin. It doesn't really do anything, just sets a bunch of default parameters. And it still requires people to update the plugin version to get the new settings. So still a somewhat manual process.

I'm not sure there's a great solution to that problem. When probably just need to remember to update scala and sbt versions when we update the daffodil dependency.
Mistake setting up. Too many commits pulled together here.

Re: Performance. I think this change can only improve performance, because instead of calling ThreadLocal.get (which calls a hashTable get), we're just directly accessing the state we already have.

I entirely agree the pools leak stuff should go. 

Some pools are "disciplined", and a macro that does the get and release could be created - I did a little web surfing about that. The now-called dfaRegisterPool is exactly this case. This is a replacement for the C++ use of an automatic/local variable that is a struct. That's all we're looking for with that sort of pool. We just want an object for a little local use. In this case using a macro that lays down a try/finally is actually adding a bunch of overhead we don't want. I'd prefer to have a macro that does the get and release, so you don't have to remember, but which doesn't use a try-catch, along with a checker at end of parse/unparse that does both a check to see if you've leaked them and resets the pool so there can't be subsequent interactions ever. 

The less-disciplined pools e.g., for marks and such in the I/O system, those are just harder, but we should actually measure if they are saving us anything. Might be better to just allocate and discard in those cases. 

If we create a ticket for "fix the pools" it should include measuring if there is any benefit, and just removing the pools that aren't helping. 

Of course something that might not be noticeable in overhead today might become so in the future.....
The underlying issue was fixed by Mike in commit 92429a0fc26673d1df362916862729c03a9c9a0a and some tests were added there so this pull request may not be needed.

A more specific test for the non-exist case is always welcome.

See ticket DAFFODIL-284 .... I added a comment near the end about how this was still happening.  

This test is ok. There is still a problem with circular group refs tho.

test_simple_type_properties_bin_calendar_13_02(org.apache.daffodil.IBMTestsThatPass)

test_alignment_bytes_12_05(org.apache.daffodil.IBMTestsThatPass2)

Added new fixup commit that removes the SimpleDateTime when creating the infoset. Avoids ThreadLocals and any overhead related to SimpleDateTIme.

Confirmed that the above tests now pass with the IBM Cross tester, plus the following tests:
* test_length_delimited_12_04
* test_length_delimited_12_01
* test_simple_type_properties_text_calendar_13_02

All tests in IBMTestsThatPass pass with IBM and all but one in IBMTestsThatPass2 pass. The one failure is unrelated to type awareness.
Need to add negative tests showing coercion errors.

Came back to this to add some negative tests, and I dont' think this is really the complete solution. This change still allows coercion in the case where the target type and the expression result type are both numeric. This is clearly wrong in the case of decimal numbers, for example:

```xml
<xs:element name="a" type="xs:int" dfdl:inputValueCalc="{ 2.5 }" />
```
In this case, we really do not want to coerce 2.5 to an int, but this change would coerce since both are numerics.  An alternative might be to require that types match exactly, but then usability suffers. For example:

```xml
<xs:element name="a" type="xs:int" dfdl:inputValueCalc="{ 2 }" />
```

In this case, the literal 2 is technically an xs:integer so the result type and target type do not match. So if we were strict about it, this simple expression requires the use of ``xs:int(2)``. That's not terrible, but there's a good chance we would probably break a lot of schemas.

Perhaps a happy medium is to allow coercion between integer-like things? So we would automatically coerece an xs:integer to an xs:int (as long as the value was in range), but would not coerece 2.5 to 2, for example. An odd side effect of this is that one could know do this:

```xml
<xs:element name="a" type="xs:int" dfdl:inputValueCalc="{ xs:integer(2) }" />
```

And we would happily coerce that, even though it seems like maybe the user intended something else since types are explicitly provided and differ. Perhaps a better solution exists? I think it would be difficult track track when types are explicit and only check in those cases, so maybe this edge case isn't worth solving.

In what way is the expression 2 not an xs:int ? Our DPath compiler might choose to make all integers xs:integer and represent them as bignums at runtime, but that's perhaps just arbitrary. 

2 fits within the range of every signed and unsigned integer decimal and floating point type.  From the type-system perspective it is of the required type. It should be accepted for any integer type at least. 

The usual approach is that conversions that preserve information content perfectly are done automatically within numeric types, but those that involve rounding/truncation are not.

According to w3c XPath, integer literals are alwyas xs:integer and then coerecion happens as needed. But this change is to disable coerecion of expression result. So technical 2 isn't an xs:int. Note that Daffodil does do some stuff to coerece literals down to int's' or long's (though I think technically this isn't spec compliant?), so 2 is probably considered an xs:int. But for example, we never coerce literals to xs:short's, so if you had something like this, it would fail without coerecion:

```xml
<xs:element name="a" type="xs:short" dfdl:inputValueCalc="{ 2 }" />
```

The suggestion of allowing coerence between types only when no rounding/truncation should occur seems reasonable. I'll try it out.
Added comments explaining the purpose of the function. Also made the function prviate to help self-document that it should only be used for testing.

Mike thought that there might be a similar case of avoiding OOLAG/LV calls for position in ElementBase, but I did not find anything obviously similar to what I changed in ModelGroup. If there is something in there, let me know and I'll add it to this pull request (or a new one).
The travis CI build failed due to rat check failure - a file was introduced that needs an apache license banner I believe.

That rat failure was introduced in commit 912f7d2b73 and we missed it. It was then fixed as part of the next commit 69bb0a185e, but this PR branched off of the earlier commit. Once the comits are squashed rebased on top of current master, we can confirm that this did not introduce any new rat failures.

Also, apparently TravisCI now supports windows:

https://blog.travis-ci.com/2018-10-11-windows-early-release

It might be a good idea to modify our .travis.yml file to enable that. There might some issues like the rpm build would probably fail on windows, but I think we can disable certain commands based on the build environment:

https://docs.travis-ci.com/user/multi-os/#example-multi-os-build-matrix
Actually, it looking more closing, TravisCI does not support java/scala yet, so we'll have to hold off on that.
Looks like the ratCheck is still failing. Can you please look into that? I think you maybe just need to fetch the latest and rebase ontop of master.
Closing. This was never intended to be merged. It's just to gather comments.

While it is nice to have a more helpful error message, I imagine that this is just one of several edge cases, not to mention that the error message is coming from the Scala RegexParsers (if I understand the code correctly), so I'm not sure it is worth making this change.  I figured I could push this up for review and see what the group decides.

Took me a bit to get the IBMCrossTester up and running and once I did I realized that the tests didn't need to be updated in order to work.  However, 2 of the tests that were listed in the DAFFODIL-2017, test_length_delimited_12_01 and 02, still fail due to IBM's implementation not allowing the separator and terminator to be the same character(s).

Added this comment to explain why these fail and mentioned bug 2018 which discusses this incompatibility.
The ratCheck failed. Can you please run that and add apache licenses to new files?
Saw Steve's comment about adding Apache headers. Will do.

> File daffodil-cli/src/windows/Product.wxs should not have been included in this commit. Please remove.

Please delete this file using ``git rm`` and create a new commit. When you push that commit, it will automatically update this pull request.

Took a little while to track this down, but ended up being a simple fix once found.  I wouldn't be surprised if there are other issues similar to this where we don't have checks in place for Parsers that will generate NadaParsers.

That said, I'm not sure we want codecov-io to add a comment to every pull request. Looks like that can be disabled with a [codecov.yml file](https://docs.codecov.io/docs/pull-request-comments)?
Just pushed up another small change, adding a .codecov.yml file, which should disable the comment creation

Re: 2.3.0 release. I think we need to check that the binary format schemas like stanag 5516, actually still work. VMF works because none of the messages we're testing use the 2045 header fields that are hexBinary with prefix length computed by a value calc. 

These might be able to be changed to use new prefixed lengthKind support, and that may be a good workaround. I'll give that a try.

I confirmed all tests with nato-stanag-5516 work (or can be made to) on 2.3.0 and updated that schema's tests to work on 2.3.0. 

I also confirmed that prefixed lengthKind can be used in the mil-std-2045 header as a workaround for the problematic hexBinary fields, so will make that change.

I believe this bug does not need to stop the release of 2.3.0 daffodil.
Above comments resolved in fixup commit.

Just added a test to confirm that BigDecimal.setScale does in fact return a copy of the original BigDecimal with its scale changed, so it is side effect free.

Might be easier to review by viewing the  what github generates: 

https://github.com/stevedlawrence/incubator-daffodil/blob/daffodil-2098-readme/README.md
New version uploaded
+1 to the new changes

It looks like this change now causes a single test to fail:
```org.apache.daffodil.section23.dfdl_expressions.TestDFDLExpressions.test_int_constructor_04```

The test expects the string "expression evaluation error". It used to get this error message:

> Parse Error: Cannot convert 'not an int!' from String type to Long (Cannot convert to type long: For input string: "not an int!"). (within Expression Evaluation Error: Cannot convert 'not an int!' from String type to Long (Cannot convert to type long: For input string: "not an int!").

But it now gets just this:

> Parse Error: Cannot convert 'not an int!' from String type to Long (Cannot convert to type long: For input string: "not an int!").

So we're losing the information that the parse error actually occurred in an expression evaluation error. There's definiately a lot of redundancy in that error message, but that fact that it occurred in an expression is useful information that I don't think we want to lose. Perhaps there's a different underlying issue here, like something using ProcessingError incorrectly? The bug mentions it's that maybeFormatString and maybeCause shouldn't both be passed in? Ifsomethign is using this incorrectly, maybe combining the paramters into a single paramter that is an ``Either[String,Throwable]`` would the type system figure out where we're doing something wrong.

It would also be helpful if you could add a tdml test that reproduces the bad error so that we can ensure the test is fixed and does not regress in the future.

@stevedlawrence 

Unfortunately, the original error (which caused the poorly behaving Parse error) was in simply broken code so I don't know of any way to trigger it from a TDML. I can probably create a unit test that exersises that particular error path.

Updating the type to be an Either type seems like the correct solution. However, as we are in the runtime system, I am wondering if the use of Maybe here was a deliberate choice for performance reasons. (I believe these objects get created routinely as part of backtracking).

I am also a bit suspicious of the way the original asymetry between the parse and unparse case:

```
def toParseError = new ParseError(schemaContext, dataContext, Maybe(this), maybeFormatString, args: _*)

def toUnparseError = new UnparseError(schemaContext, dataContext, maybeCause, maybeFormatString, args: _*)
``` 

Since you are not allowed to have both maybeCause and maybeFormatString, I didn't see how the parse case could ever be correct, so I just copied the unparse case. (In particular, a caller may never pass maybeFormatString to ProcessingError if it would ever be converted to a ParseError, and I suspect that calling _.toParseError.toParseError will behave silly in that the error will be nested an additional time for each call.)

Looking at the code, it seems the info being lost by not including "this" as the cause is the modeName arguement passed to the outer ProcessingError ("Expression Evaluation" in this case). Unfortunately, ParseError makes a point of being a "Parse" error which, by definition, overwrites the value of modeName with "Parse".

Maybe it makes sense for modeName to be some sort of list? so the generated error looks more like:

```
Parse Error: Expression Evaluation Error: Cannot convert 'not an int!' from String type to Long (Cannot convert to type long: For input string: "not an int!").
```

(The repetition of "Error" is independent, but probably a good idea from the perspective of string matching).
This didn't work as cleanly as I expected, closing for now and will re-open once #202 is accepted.

For reference, here is the Azure build I set up:

https://dev.azure.com/stevedlawrence/incubator-daffodil.git/_build?definitionId=2

Sorry, I missed your statement about not being done yet, so ignore my comments about dealing with TODO's, etc.

I haven't gotten through everything yet, but I've only noticed some small formatting things, so things are looking good so far.

Yes I think both toParseError and toUnparseError should be using Maybe(this) for the cause. Both should be chaining the exceptions the same way.

The concept here. Innermost exception specifies a format string. Enclosing exceptions have causes only, and *never* have format strings. At actual message creation time each exception contributes to the ultimate message string based on its class name. 

So you should get "Parse Error (caused by) Expression Evaluation Error: actual message string from innermost class goes here". Though I think "(caused by)" is a bit much. I'd just use a ":".
Just pushed up a small fix to the test and rebased off of the most recent approved commits, which fixed the issue preventing the passing test from round tripping.
Also, commit message is missing a bug number.
Commit message updated

Closed. Will address the tool for maintaining these classpaths, and probably once that is fixed we need to just remove the eclipse-isms from the check-in. 

Might make sense to even just get rid of the entire eclipse-projects substructure (or generate all of it).

I believe we determined this interesting layering transform isn't actually required for the data format we thought needed it.

So do we want to incorporate this into Daffodil, or abandon it. 

I suggest keeping the branch even if we don't incorporate it. We might build a tutorial around it "how to write a layering addition to Daffodil", and use this sort of thing as a non-trivial motivating example.

I'd vote to just close this pull request rather than incorporating it. If we incorporate, it's just one more thing we need to support and maintain.

Note that we don't really need to keep the branch around if we do close it. Even in that case, the PR and all its comments will always exist. And the PR branch can always be fetched with
```
git fetch origin refs/pull/210/head:pr-210
```
So it is effectively part of the repository, just not one that is as visible.

I'd also say that this commit isn't that good of a tutorial for how to add a layer. It's fairly complex, and adds new features (e.g. layer arguments) that most layering things won't need. A tutorial would be good, but this has too much overhead, IMO.
I can go with that.
Closing sounds good to me as well.

Didn't realize I never gave a +1. I think all my comments have been addressed. This is a much needed addition.

+1 :+1:

I also wanted to comment on backward compatibility.

This new functionality is NOT 100% backward compatible. Several pre-existing DFDL schemas no longer function the exact same way. These are FOUO schemas like agnosc_remedy. 

The way they are different is that Daffodil (this branch anyway) is more compliant with the DFDL spec now, so the test cases for these older schemas are relying on non-compliant behavior.  We can obviously fix the tests that come with those schemas, but other projects and systems will have schemas that may also see subtle behavior changes (especially around when empty elements are created as part of the infoset).

I'm not sure what to do about this. We already have two behavior modes here. One for IBM DFDL's legacy behavior. The other for what I believe is DFDL spec compliant behavior. Adding yet another for Daffodil's legacy behavior will be hard, as characterizing exactly how it is non-compliant is not simple.

@mbeckerle I don't think we can merge DState with P/UState. We need to have a (degenerate) DState without a P/UState for constant folding. I also think it makes sense to keep them seperate just as an organizational matter, as our DPath interperatetor is relatively isolated from our main DFDL interperator. A back pointer is probably the way to go.

Having said that, it might make sense to merge a bunch of the setters. Now that we are passing in a pointer to the entire state, we might want to stop passing in pointers to indiviual fields of the state, and replace them with functions in DState that refer to the main state object.

w.r.t the issue of merging DState and P/UState I see your point that it's better to keep them separate, but we need a trait that defines the dependencies of DState on P/UState if the separation is going to be worth much. Would probably make DState more testable in isolation also.
All thread safety issues should hopefully be addressed now.

A thought. This change introduces 41 deprecation errors. I had to switch off the checking that fails on warnings when compiling scala code. 

 Do we want a dev branch for this until those are resolved? (It will not be quick to resolve them all.)

> A thought. This change introduces 41 deprecation errors. I had to switch off the checking that fails on warnings when compiling scala code.
> 
> Do we want a dev branch for this until those are resolved? (It will not be quick to resolve them all.)

I don't think a separate dev branch is necessary at the momemt. As long as things aren't broken, I'd prefer to get changes in master as soon as possible to minimize issues dealing with merge conflicts in the future and get people used to the new stuff.

I'd suggest either
1. Turn off ``-Xfatal-warnings`` as you did
2. Turn off ``-deprecation`` until the deprecated functions are removed. People trying to remove these deprecated functions can turn it back on during development to find the uses of deprecated functions.
3. Just don't deprecate those functions at all and just work to eventually remove them. We can make sure during reviews that new code added doesn't use them.

One must turn off both deprecation warnings and Xfatal-warnings to successfully compile. Because even if you turn off deprecation warnings, you still get summary warnings that there were 41 deprecation warnings total, and with Xfatal-warnings, those stop the compilation from succeeding.

I've concluded the right thing is to remove as many deprecated calls as possible (some calls were from unused/dead code), and then comment out the deprecate annotations for now so we're back to zero warnings. These can be commented back in to pursue this particular thread of improvements.

The idea is to insure invariants the software depends on are being upheld. This particular invariant is that any sequence, even just the one implied when a choice has an array element child, can be asked for its format annotation object, and one is positively returned, even if it's an empty one containing no annotations. 

The separators of an enclosing sequence do not appear around array element occurrences for a choice branch that is an array element. To achieve that you need an explicit sequence surrounding the array element so you can express the separator. 

The rationale here is that choices don't get to express separator properties, but that's where they would have to appear if the choice branch (that is an array element) was to have separators. 

I suppose the alternative would be to say choices are transparent to separation by an enclosing sequence. But that's not true if the choice expresses initiator/terminator, which choices are allowed to have.  I lost this battle long ago in the DFDL Workgroup. My position was only sequences should have delimiters of any kind, period, but this did not win the day, as other existing format description systems including some based on XSD, allowed these sorts of properties to be expressed on a variety of constructs.

Re 2) .toSeq returns an immutable Seq.
Looking at the scala changelog https://github.com/scala/scala/releases/tag/v2.13.0 I believe what actually changed is the build it "Seq" type is now an alias for collection.immutable.Seq. Previously, it had meant collections.Seq, which includes mutable implementations.
